Authors:
Dhanushka Nadeeshan Wanasinghe, Nalin Wijayawardene,
Jian-Chu Xu, Ratchadawan Cheewangkoon, Peter E Mortimer
Title:
Based on morphology and multi-gene phylogenetic evidences of
the collected ascomycetes, we characterized a new family, a neotype, a
new species and a new host record in the order Pleosporales.
Abstract:
Yunnan Province, China, is an important part of the
Greater Mekong Subregion. The area is a biodiversity hotspot and is home
to an extremely high amount of microfungal diversity. The highly
variable climate and vast range of floral diversity indicates that the
area is favorable for rapid fungal growth and reproduction. During the
last several decades, macrofungi from Yunnan occurring across different
substrates have been published and reclassified, introducing many new
species to science. However, microfungi still suffer from numerous gaps
in knowledge around species diversity and systematics. Basic information
of microfungi, such as taxonomic diversity, molecular phylogeny,
ecological roles, biogeographic distributions, host-specificity and
co-evolutionary relationships, is still lacking throughout Yunnan
Province. To address this knowledge deficit, we collected plants
associated with aboveground microfungi from every county of Yunnan
Province. This paper represents the first article in a series on
Yunnanese microfungi, and we provide insights into Magnolia species
associated with microfungi that resulted in the characterization of a
new family, a neotype, a new species, and a host record. All data
presented herein are based on morphological examination of specimens,
coupled with phylogenetic sequence data to better integrate taxa into
appropriate taxonomic ranks and infer their relationships.
